data.name: Swinging factorials
data.description:
## Introduction

You've probably heard of factorials and there's a chance you've written, or attempted, to create some code which can calculate them.  There is a lesser known variant of factorials known as swinging factorials, of which the first few are 1, 1, 2, 6, 6, ...


## Definition

Swinging factorials have a technical definition:

>a(n) is the number of vertices of the polytope resulting from the intersection of an n-hypercube with the hyperplane perpendicular to and bisecting one of its long diagonals. - Didier Guillet, Jun 11 2018

That probably doesn't help much, so, to get you started, here's a definition:

```math
\begin{cases}
   s_0 = 1 \\
   s_n = n^{n \text{ mod } 2} * (4/n)^{(n+1)\text{ mod } 2} * a_{n-1} &\text{for } n \geqslant 1
\end{cases}
```

If recursive definitions just aren't your thing (no judgement here!) there are alternatives, the discovery of which I shall leave as a classic 'exercise for the student'...


# The problem

Write a function which generates the swinging factorial for a given positive integer, n.

All of the tests inputs will be valid, so there's no need to validate them.

## Hint

Swinging factorials are one of the sequences in the [OEIS](https://oeis.org/).

## Bigger Hint

[This](https://oeis.org/A056040) is the OEIS page you're looking for.
